questions.text: Three days after delivery, a 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 25 seconds. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past 18 hours. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She appears ill. Her pulse is 123/min, respirations are 50/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If left untreated, classic galactosemia may manifest with lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures, as seen here. However, the absence of cataracts (typically manifests within the first days of life), jaundice, and hepatomegaly make this diagnosis less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Spinal muscular atrophy is a possible cause of muscular hypotonia in infants. The most severe type (Werdnig-Hoffmann disease) may manifest immediately after birth or up to 6 months of age. Proximal muscles, mostly of the lower extremities, are usually involved symmetrically. However, seizures, a tense anterior fontanelle, impaired pupillary response, and roving eye movements would not be consistent with this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

While most patients are asymptomatic at birth, half of the patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) have seizures with cerebral foci, a lag of psychomotor development, and a musty body odor by 4–6 months of age. Additional features include light, pale hair and blue eyes (due to decreased melanin production). Since most patients are asymptomatic until severe and often irreversible complications have occurred, direct measurement of phenylalanine levels is an important part of newborn screening for metabolic disorders. The screening test is performed on the second day after birth using blood obtained from a heel prick.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydrocephalus due to congenital causes, such as the Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker malformation, and intrauterine infections, may manifest in neonates with lethargy, tense fontanelles, seizures, and changes in vital signs due to brain stem compression (e.g., irregular breathing). However, elevated intracranial pressure usually manifests with rapidly increasing circumference of the head in neonates, which is not seen in this infant. Furthermore, instead of the roving eye movements, a downward deviation of the eyes (sunset eye sign) would be expected in patients with hydrocephalus.

E) CORRECT:

Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is a common complication in preterm infants and usually occurs within the first five days after birth. This complication is typically seen in neonates of < 1500 g birth weight and born before 32 weeks' gestation due to the fragility of the germinal matrix. Additional risk factors include peripartal chorioamnionitis and hypoxia (as suggested by this patient's low Apgar scores). Most infants with IVH are asymptomatic, but saltatory (over several days) or, more rarely, catastrophic (over minutes to hours) courses are also possible. Symptoms include lethargy, hypotonia, irregular respirations, bulging anterior fontanelle, and neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures, cranial nerve abnormalities as suggested by poor pupillary light reflexes and roving eye movements), all of which this patient has.

Cranial ultrasonography is the preferred method to diagnose IVH in newborns. Since most patients are asymptomatic, screening ultrasounds are routinely performed in infants with a birth weight < 1500 g and delivery before 30 weeks' gestation.
Image Description:

Ultrasound head (top row: coronal plane; bottom row: parasagittal plane) of a newborn

The first column shows bleeding confined to the subependymal germinal matrix (red overlay), which is consistent with grade 1 IVH.
The second column shows blood occupying less than 50% of the left lateral ventricle (red overlay), with no enlargement of the lateral ventricles (yellow overlay) or the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay). In addition, the choroid plexus is clearly demarcated (blue overlay). Together, these findings are consistent with grade 2 IVH.
The third column shows blood occupying more than 50% of the lateral ventricles (red overlay) with enlargement of the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay) and both lateral ventricles (yellow overlay). This appearance is consistent with grade 3 IVH.

These features suggest impaired progressive posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation (PHVD) due to associated impairment of CSF circulation, which is a potential complication of high-grade IVH.
questions.hint: The condition described here is a serious complication of preterm birth.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of a gush of clear fluid from her vagina that occurred 1 hour prior. She reports painful pelvic cramping at regular 5-minute intervals. She has missed most of her prenatal care visit because of financial problems from her recent divorce. Her first child was delivered vaginally at 27 weeks' gestation due to spontaneous preterm labor. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years but has reduced her intake to 2–3 cigarettes per day since finding out she was pregnant. She continues to use cocaine once a week. Vital signs are within normal limits. Sterile speculum examination shows fluid pooling in the vagina, and nitrazine paper testing confirms the presence of amniotic fluid. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for preterm delivery in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low maternal socioeconomic status, maternal income, and educational level, as well as single marital status and help from professional agencies, are known risk factors associated with preterm delivery. Although this woman has financial problems and recently had a divorce (factors that may be associated with preterm birth), her socioeconomic status is not the strongest risk factor.

B) INCORRECT:

Lack of (especially early) prenatal care is often associated with a low maternal socioeconomic status, which is in turn is associated with mainly behavioral risk factors of preterm delivery. This woman has missed several prenatal care visits, which contributes to an increased risk for preterm birth. However, it is not the strongest risk factor.

C) INCORRECT:

Maternal smoking during pregnancy is an independent risk factor for preterm delivery. Furthermore, it is associated with placental abruption, placenta previa, intrauterine growth restriction, and premature rupture of membranes, all predisposing factors for preterm birth. However, the relationship is only moderate and also dose-dependent, accounting only for a weak increase in risk in this woman who cut down her cigarette consumption.

D) INCORRECT:

Substance abuse during pregnancy is associated with premature birth. Especially the use of cocaine increases the risk of placental abruption, placental insufficiency, and preterm labor, all of which can result in preterm delivery. However, this woman's substance abuse is not the strongest risk factor for preterm birth.

E) INCORRECT:

This woman had a recent divorce, which suggests psychosocial stress during pregnancy. Although it is difficult to study this relationship, stress has been shown to moderately increase the risk of preterm birth. However, it is not the strongest risk factor in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Both young (< 21 years) and advanced (> 35 years) maternal age are associated with preterm delivery. This may be partially due to confounding factors, such as a lower socioeconomic status and immaturity of the genital organs for young mothers, chronic diseases and obesity for older mothers, or undesired pregnancies in both age groups. In this patient's case, there is a stronger risk factor for preterm delivery.

G) CORRECT:

This patient presents with preterm premature rupture of membranes and possibly preterm labor (suggested by painful pelvic cramping at regular 5-minute intervals), which are both concerning for imminent preterm delivery. A history of spontaneous preterm birth (PTB) is the strongest predisposing factor for recurrence. The risk increases with the number of previous PTBs and decreases with the number of term deliveries between the PTB and the current pregnancy. The timing of the recurrent PTB is often similar to the previous one(s). This patient's first child was delivered at 27 weeks' gestation, and she does not have a history of term delivery since then. Therefore, she is at increased risk for preterm delivery during this pregnancy, especially since the fetus is almost the same gestational age.
questions.hint: This patient presents with several risk factors for preterm labor and delivery; however, one of them is particularly strong.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 31 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital because of spontaneous onset of labor. Pregnancy has been complicated by iron deficiency anemia and hypothyroidism treated with iron supplements and levothyroxine. The patient followed up with her gynecologist on a regular basis throughout the pregnancy. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. She has no known drug allergies. Pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender. She has had 8 contractions within the last hour. Pelvic examination shows cervical dilation of 3 cm. The fetal heart rate is 140/min with no decelerations. In addition to administration of dexamethasone and indomethacin, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the setting of pregnancy, dilation and curettage are indicated in the management of a missed abortion, incomplete abortion, or induced abortion. This patient has a viable fetus in the 31st week of gestation and requires active management of preterm labor.

B) INCORRECT:

Since this patient is at 31 weeks' gestation and there is no immediate risk of maternal or fetal demise, the main priority is to delay delivery for up to 48 hours to allow antenatal corticosteroids to be administered and provide prophylaxis against cerebral palsy. Emergency cesarean delivery is indicated in cases of severe vaginal bleeding (e.g., suspected uterine rupture), nonreassuring fetal signs (pathological cardiotocography), or immediate risk of death for either mother or child.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical cerclage is the definitive treatment of cervical insufficiency during pregnancy. It is contraindicated in women who are already in labor and is, therefore, not an option in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-Rhesus D immunoglobulins are administered in rhesus-negative women who are unsensitized to anti-D antibodies to prevent Rhesus D hemolytic disease of the newborn. It is typically administered in the 28th week of gestation and within 72 hours after birth. This patient's Rhesus D status is not mentioned. However, the routine prenatal visits, which include ABO and Rhesus D typing, did not show any abnormalities, making this an unlikely complication. More importantly, this patient is in preterm labor and requires active management.

E) CORRECT:

Fetal neuroprotection with magnesium sulfate is indicated if preterm delivery < 32 weeks' gestation is anticipated (e.g., in preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes). In addition, magnesium sulfate has tocolytic properties and can be administered as a single agent or in combination with another tocolytic agent (e.g., indomethacin for patients at ≤ 32 weeks' gestation) to delay preterm labor for up to 48 hours. A delay of this duration allows for the full effect of antenatal corticosteroids to induce fetal lung maturity. Since this patient in preterm labor has an unknown group B streptococcal (GBS) infection status, prophylaxis for neonatal GBS infection with either IV penicillin G or ampicillin every 4 hours until delivery is also required.

Concomitant administration of magnesium sulfate and a calcium channel blocker (e.g., nifedipine) for tocolysis should be avoided because of the high risk of side effects.

F) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy is indicated in patients with premature labor and unknown group B streptococcal (GBS) infection status as prophylaxis for neonatal GBS infection. However, a first-line agent such as penicillin G or ampicillin is more appropriate than azithromycin.

Azithromycin is indicated in patients with preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) as part of an antibiotic regimen to delay the onset of preterm labor resulting from maternal or fetal infection (latency antibiotics). For patients with PPROM, two antibiotics targeting GBS (e.g., amoxicillin and ampicillin) are given in combination with azithromycin, which primarily provides coverage against Ureaplasma and Chlamydia trachomatis. This patient has preterm labor with no evidence to suggest prior PPROM; therefore, a different step in management is necessary.
questions.hint: This patient is in preterm labor and prophylaxis against cerebral palsy is indicated.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 1, at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal care visit. She used fertility-enhancing treatment for her current pregnancy. Her first pregnancy resulted in a spontaneous abortion at 18 weeks' gestation. In her last pregnancy, the child was born at 26 weeks' gestation after a precipitous, painless vaginal delivery. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nontender and no contractions are felt. Ultrasonography shows a cervical length of 22 mm and a fetal heart rate of 140/min. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cephalopelvic disproportion is a condition in which the size of the fetal head is too large for the maternal pelvis. Possible causes include fetal macrosomia due to maternal diabetes mellitus, post-term pregnancy, and an abnormally shaped pelvis, none of which is the case in this patient. Moreover, CPD is a condition that is clinically diagnosed during labor and does not manifest with cervical shortening.

B) INCORRECT:

A bicornuate uterus may cause infertility but does not usually manifest with cervical shortening. Additionally, bicornuate uterus is diagnosed by ultrasonography and was not observed in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Placental insufficiency is a pregnancy complication that either manifests acutely in the third trimester, resulting in sudden fetal hypoxia and/or intrauterine death, or is present throughout pregnancy. Chronic placental insufficiency is caused by maternal conditions (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hypertension) that gradually impair fetal blood supply, leading to intrauterine growth restriction and death if not treated. There is no evidence of placental insufficiency in this pregnancy, which would take the form of a non-reassuring fetal heart rate or signs of placental malperfusion on ultrasound.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's obstetric history suggests cervical insufficiency, which manifests during the second trimester and leads to an inability to maintain pregnancy in the absence of contractions or other underlying causes (e.g., infection, premature rupture of membranes). The diagnosis is established in women who either present with current painless cervical dilation or have a history of painless cervical dilation after the first trimester with subsequent pregnancy loss or preterm birth in the absence of other underlying causes. Cervical insufficiency is an indication for transvaginal cervical cerclage for individuals at < 24 weeks' gestation to prevent potential pregnancy loss and preterm birth.

A shortened cervical length is not sufficient to diagnose cervical insufficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

While ultrasound shows a normal heart rate and no fetal abnormalities, the mother's obstetric history indicates a condition that considerably increases the risk of pregnancy loss and preterm birth.
questions.hint: A history of second-trimester pregnancy loss and preterm birth following a painless vaginal delivery should raise concern for a specific condition.

questions.text: Three weeks after birth, a newborn girl develops episodes of respiratory arrest. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past two days and today experienced two episodes in which she stopped breathing for 10 seconds. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation and weighed 1600 g (3 lb 8 oz). Apgar scores were 4 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 185/min, respirations are 60/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 70/35 mm Hg. She appears pale. Physical examination shows pallor of the mucous membranes and no other abnormalities. Hemoglobin is 6.5 g/dL, reticulocyte count is 0.5%, and mean corpuscular volume is 92 μm3. Leukocyte count, platelet count, total bilirubin, and indirect bilirubin are all within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's anemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired synthesis of hemoglobin β-chain causes beta thalassemia. The switch from fetal HbF, which contains hemoglobin gamma-chains instead of beta-chains, to HbA, which contains beta-chains, happens gradually after birth. Therefore, newborns with beta thalassemia are typically asymptomatic until around 6 months of age, unlike this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

An x-linked recessive defect in δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase is the genetic defect that gives rise to inherited cases of sideroblastic anemia, which typically presents as microcytic anemia (MCV < 80 μm3). While X-linked recessive disorders predominantly present in men, about ⅓ of cases of X-linked sideroblastic anemias are middle-aged women, due to X chromosome inactivation in red cell progenitors that can occur with advancing age. Sideroblastic anemia would be a very unlikely diagnosis in a 3-week-old female infant.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow suppression results in aplastic anemia and can be caused by inherited disorders (e.g., Fanconi anemia), medication side effects/toxicity, and infections such as parvovirus B19, hepatitis viruses, Epstein-Barr virus, and HIV. Congenital conditions such as Fanconi anemia or Diamond-Blackfan anemia typically manifest with skeletal abnormalities (e.g., microcephaly, thumb malformations), which are absent in this newborn. She also has no signs of infection (e.g., fever) and does not receive medications. Lastly, aplastic anemia would present with pancytopenia.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that very rarely presents in female individuals. Additionally, it is a hemolytic anemia that presents after a sudden surge in oxidative stress, such as infection or medications. As this infant has normal levels of total bilirubin and indirect bilirubin, without any recent infection or medication use, she likely does not have hemolytic anemia.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Premature infants are at a higher risk for iron deficiency anemia due to shortened maternal-fetal iron transfer and reduced gastrointestinal absorption after birth. However, iron deficiency typically results in microcytic, hypochromic anemia when symptomatic rather than this patient's normocytic anemia.

F) CORRECT:

Impaired production of erythropoietin (EPO) is the primary cause of anemia of prematurity (AOP). EPO is produced by the fetal liver as well as fetal kidneys and production increases with gestational age. EPO levels and erythropoiesis show a physiological decrease after birth, as the onset of breathing and the closure of the ductus arteriosus increase tissue oxygenation. Preterm children are born with a lower hematocrit than full-term newborns, which is complicated by the physiologically reduced EPO production after birth. This effect results in AOP. Poor oxygen delivery to the tissue leads to clinical signs and symptoms of AOP (e.g., episodes of apnea). Laboratory findings for AOP include normocytic, normochromic anemia with a low-normal reticulocyte count, all of which are present in this patient.

Management of AOP includes limitation of blood withdrawals, iron supplementation (routinely done in preterm infants), and RBC transfusions if necessary (taking into account restrictive guidelines for transfusions in neonates). Erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (e.g., recombinant EPO) are not routinely administered due to limited efficacy and severe side effects (e.g., retinopathy of prematurity). Anemia is typically self-limiting and resolves around three to six months of age.
questions.hint: This patient presents with severe anemia and episodes of apnea, which are most likely caused by poor tissue oxygenation. Her condition manifests in premature infants typically at the age of 3–12 weeks.

questions.text: Four days after delivery, a 1400-g (3-lb 1-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 30 seconds. Over the past 24 hours, he has become increasingly lethargic. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 4 and 5 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He appears ill. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 53/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 67/35 mm Hg. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase deficiency is the underlying cause of galactosemia, which, if left untreated, may present with lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures, as seen here. However, the absence of cataracts (may present within the first days of life), jaundice, and hepatomegaly, make this diagnosis less likely.

Galactosemia can cause coagulopathy and increased risk of bleeding, which may predispose children to the condition of this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Apoptosis of lower motor neurons is the underlying mechanism of spinal muscular atrophy, which is a possible cause of muscular hypotonia in infants. The most severe type (Werdnig-Hoffmann disease) may manifest immediately after birth or up to 6 months of age. Proximal muscles, mostly of the lower extremities, are usually involved symmetrically. However, this patient's seizures, bulging anterior fontanelle, impaired pupillary response, and roving eye movements would not be consistent with this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrocephalus due to congenital causes, such as the Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker malformation, and intrauterine infections, may present in neonates with lethargy, tense fontanelles, seizures, and changes in vital signs due to brain stem compression (e.g., irregular breathing). However, elevated intracranial pressure usually manifests with rapidly increasing circumference of the head in neonates, which is not seen in this infant. Furthermore, instead of the roving eye movements, a downward deviation of the eyes (sunset eye sign) would be expected in patients with hydrocephalus.

D) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency is the underlying cause of phenylketonuria. While most patients are asymptomatic at birth, half of patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) have seizures with cerebral foci, a lag of psychomotor development and a musty body odor by 4–6 months of age. Additional features include light, pale hair and blue eyes (due to decreased melanin production). Since most patients are asymptomatic until severe and often irreversible complications have occurred, direct measurement of phenylalanine levels is an important part of newborn screening for metabolic disorders. The screening test is performed on the second day after birth using blood obtained from a heel prick.

E) CORRECT:

Germinal matrix hemorrhage is the underlying cause of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) in preterm infants. IVH is a common complication in preterm infants that usually occurs within the first five days after birth. It is typically seen in neonates weighing < 1500 g and born before 32 weeks' gestation due to the fragility of the germinal matrix. Additional risk factors include peripartal chorioamnionitis and hypoxia (as suggested by this patient's low Apgar scores). Most infants with IVH are asymptomatic, but saltatory (over several days) or, more rarely, catastrophic (over minutes to hours) courses are also possible. Symptoms include lethargy, hypotonia, irregular respirations, seizures, bulging anterior fontanelle, cranial nerve abnormalities (e.g., pupil reacting sluggishly to light), and changes in eye movement (e.g., roving eye movements), all of which this patient has.

Cranial ultrasonography is the preferred method to diagnose IVH in the newborn. Since most patients are asymptomatic, screening ultrasounds are routinely performed in infants with a birth weight < 1500 g and delivery before 30 weeks' gestation.
Image Description:

Ultrasound head (top row: coronal plane; bottom row: parasagittal plane) of a newborn

The first column shows bleeding confined to the subependymal germinal matrix (red overlay), which is consistent with grade 1 IVH.
The second column shows blood occupying less than 50% of the left lateral ventricle (red overlay), with no enlargement of the lateral ventricles (yellow overlay) or the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay). In addition, the choroid plexus is clearly demarcated (blue overlay). Together, these findings are consistent with grade 2 IVH.
The third column shows blood occupying more than 50% of the lateral ventricles (red overlay) with enlargement of the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay) and both lateral ventricles (yellow overlay). This appearance is consistent with grade 3 IVH.

These features suggest impaired progressive posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation (PHVD) due to associated impairment of CSF circulation, which is a potential complication of high-grade IVH.
questions.hint: The condition described here is a serious complication of preterm birth.

questions.text: One week after discharge from the neonatal intensive care unit to a regular pediatric ward, a 1450-g (3-lb 1-oz) male infant has respiratory distress and wheezing. After birth, the patient was intubated and mechanically ventilated for 3 weeks because of hypoxia. He required a 60% fraction of inspired oxygen to achieve adequate oxygen saturation. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 65/35 mm Hg. Physical examination shows labored breathing, intercostal retractions, and crackles at both lung bases. There is bluish discoloration around the lips. An x-ray of the chest shows interspersed areas of atelectasis, granular densities, and hyperinflation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchiolitis obliterans (BO) can manifest with features of respiratory distress (e.g., intercostal retractions, tachypnea, cyanosis), nonspecific auscultatory findings including wheezing and crackles, and hyperinflation on chest x-ray due to air-trapping, which are seen here. However, pediatric BO typically occurs following a severe lung infection, especially adenovirus pneumonia, and the clinical features of BO develop over years with a waxing and waning course. BO would be unlikely in this infant with no history of significant infection.

B) CORRECT:

Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) due to barotrauma and oxygen toxicity is a complication of prolonged mechanical ventilation in premature infants. This infant has classic features of BPD, which include new-onset respiratory distress, cyanosis due to hypoxemia, and chest x-ray findings such as granular densities and hyperinflation interspersed with areas of atelectasis. Treatment of BPD is primarily focused on limiting oxygen toxicity and preventing complications (e.g., pneumothorax, cardiovascular collapse, neonatal sepsis).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view) of an intubated newborn with bronchopulmonary dysplasia

Ill-defined reticular markings (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and small rounded lucent areas (examples indicated by green arrowheads) are diffusely present throughout both lungs.

An endotracheal tube (green overlay), nasogastric tube (red overlay), and central venous catheter (yellow overlay) are properly positioned. Rotation of the patient to the left has resulted in an appearance of elongation of the left ribs compared to the right ribs and leftward positioning of the cardiomediastinal silhouette.

C) INCORRECT:

Newborns with meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS) develop hypoxia immediately after birth and may require mechanical ventilation. Also, a chest x-ray in MAS would show interspersed areas of atelectasis and hyperinflation, which are seen here. However, MAS typically occurs in term and post-term rather than preterm infants; this infant's low body weight suggests that he was born preterm. Moreover, MAS would not explain the new-onset respiratory distress that occurred in this patient one week after discharge from the NICU. In infants with a history of MAS, cyanosis can remain even after the clinical features of MAS resolve if persistent pulmonary hypertension develops. However, chest x-ray is usually normal and crackles would not be expected in such a scenario.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a female neonate

Irregular opacities are present throughout both lungs (examples indicated by green overlay). The lung volumes are large as a result of air trapping.

Dashed lines: diaphragmatic cupola; red line: gastric tube; yellow overlay: central venous catheter

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary hypoplasia manifests in the neonatal period with features of respiratory distress (e.g., intercostal retractions, tachypnea, cyanosis). However, neither wheezing nor crackles would be expected, and a chest x-ray would show decreased lung volume instead of atelectasis interspersed with hyperinflation. In addition, newborns with this condition typically have other congenital abnormalities (e.g., Potter sequence, rib deformities, anasarca, scaphoid abdomen) as a result of the pathological processes that ultimately lead to pulmonary hypoplasia (e.g., oligohydramnios, thoracic dystrophy, fetal hydrops, diaphragmatic hernia). None of these congenital abnormalities are reported in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

This infant has several risk factors for pneumonia, including prematurity and prolonged intubation. Although aspects of his clinical presentation are consistent with pneumonia (e.g., labored breathing, cyanosis, crackles), other features of neonatal infection such as lethargy, temperature instability, and poor perfusion would be expected. Typical chest x-ray findings of neonatal pneumonia include bilateral alveolar densities with air bronchograms or irregular patchy infiltrates. This patient's x-ray findings are more consistent with a different condition.
questions.hint: This infant's low weight and history of NICU admission suggest that he was born preterm. Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is a common complication of preterm infants, which can require intubation in severe cases. This patient is most likely presenting with a complication of prolonged mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 23 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated and she received all routine prenatal care. Her first child was delivered at 36 weeks' gestation via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder that was treated with sertraline 2 years ago. She smokes one cigarette per day and drinks one to two beers on weekends. She does not use illicit drugs. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. She is 167 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 65 kg; BMI is 23 kg/m2. Physical examination shows a soft abdomen without any contractions. The uterus is consistent in size with a 23-week gestation. Pelvic examination shows a closed cervix without evidence of vaginal discharge or spotting. Which of the following tests is most appropriate for assessing the risk of preterm delivery in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cervicovaginal fetal fibronectin (fFN) detection test may help to predict the risk of preterm birth in women with early evidence of labor (i.e., preterm contraction). This patient is at high risk of preterm delivery due to her advanced maternal age, history of previous preterm birth, smoking, and alcohol consumption, but she has no evidence of preterm labor.

B) INCORRECT:

Doppler velocimetry of the umbilical artery is useful to assess for placental insufficiency in cases of fetal intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), which may lead to preterm delivery. However, Doppler velocimetry has no direct predictive value for preterm delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

Cell-free fetal DNA testing can be performed starting at 9–10 weeks' gestation to identify fetal chromosomal aberrations, which are a risk factor for preterm delivery. However, cell-free fetal DNA testing is not commonly performed to assess the risk of preterm birth.

D) CORRECT:

Cervical insufficiency is associated with an increased risk of preterm delivery. In women with risk factors for preterm delivery (e.g., advanced maternal age, history of previous preterm birth, smoking), a screening transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) is performed between 16 and 24 weeks' gestation to measure cervical length. A short cervical length (< 25 mm) on TVUS indicates a high risk of cervical insufficiency and preterm delivery. Progesterone supplementation or cervical cerclage may help to prolong pregnancy in women with a short cervix.

E) INCORRECT:

A fetal biophysical profile can be performed in high-risk pregnancies to evaluate the risk of antenatal fetal death and may be useful in this patient who is of advanced maternal age, smokes, and drinks alcohol. However, a biophysical profile is usually only performed after 28 weeks' gestation, while this patient is at 23 weeks' gestation, and it does not help to predict preterm delivery.
questions.hint: This test assesses one of the early steps in the events leading up to labor, which may begin some time before actual labor.
